page.title: 12Farming and Agriculture
page.content: With the exception of some of the marshy land to the north of Kemsley Mill all of the region is high grade agricultural land. Twenty years ago half of the area was covered with orchards growing cherries, plums and pears. Our survey showed that all of the cherry orchards had gone and been ploughed up to plant cereal crops or oil seed rape. Where possible fields have been combined to make larger more manageable areas and apart from a few fields which were intensively farmed to grow market garden produce, and a few which still had permenant grass, cereals and rape were the only crops. With the exception of the Coldharbour Marshes we saw very few sheep, no cows and a few cattle for fattening. Many chemicals are used in farming today and their effect on the health of the population is underestimated.
